coredata.dc:description: Ether-based polymer electrolyte shows promising potential for application in solid-state lithium batteries owing to its cost-effectiveness, excellent flexibility, and above all, remarkable stability to lithium metal anode. However, it still suffers from challenges related to low ionic conductivity and inferior oxidation resistance. Herein, an ether-based gel composite electrolyte containing Li6.5La3Zr1.5Ta0.5O12 (LLZTO) ceramics (LL-GCE) is fabricated via an in-situ polymerization method which can guarantee good interface contact with electrodes. The ceramics not only activate the interaction between polymers and lithium salts, resulting in significantly enhanced ionic conductivity (7.9 × 10−4 S cm−1), but also collaborate with poly(1,3-dioxolane) (PDOL) to construct favorable anion-rich solvation configurations, which effectively restrict the anion migration with Li+ transference number significantly increased to 0.83. Furthermore, the regulated solvation structures can passivate the electrode surface with a high content of robust LiF components formed on the electrolyte/electrode interphase. Consequently, the composite electrolyte demonstrates excellent abilities to inhibit Li dendrite growth and match with high-voltage cathodes. For instance, the LiFePO4||Li cell using such electrolyte conveys a capacity of 135.4mAh/g and the capacity retention is 99.3 % after 250 cycles at 1C. The LiCoO2||Li full cell also shows excellent cycling performance. This work provides an effective strategy to modify ether-based polymer electrolytes and can boost their development in high-performance solid state lithium metal batteries.

head.ce:title: In situ construction of ether-based composite electrolyte with stable electrode interphase for high-performance solid state lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Ether-based polymer electrolyte shows promising potential for application in solid-state lithium batteries owing to its cost-effectiveness, excellent flexibility, and above all, remarkable stability to lithium metal anode. However, it still suffers from challenges related to low ionic conductivity and inferior oxidation resistance. Herein, an ether-based gel composite electrolyte containing Li6.5La3Zr1.5Ta0.5O12 (LLZTO) ceramics (LL-GCE) is fabricated via an in-situ polymerization method which can guarantee good interface contact with electrodes. The ceramics not only activate the interaction between polymers and lithium salts, resulting in significantly enhanced ionic conductivity (7.9 × 10−4 S cm−1), but also collaborate with poly(1,3-dioxolane) (PDOL) to construct favorable anion-rich solvation configurations, which effectively restrict the anion migration with Li+ transference number significantly increased to 0.83. Furthermore, the regulated solvation structures can passivate the electrode surface with a high content of robust LiF components formed on the electrolyte/electrode interphase. Consequently, the composite electrolyte demonstrates excellent abilities to inhibit Li dendrite growth and match with high-voltage cathodes. For instance, the LiFePO4||Li cell using such electrolyte conveys a capacity of 135.4mAh/g and the capacity retention is 99.3 % after 250 cycles at 1C. The LiCoO2||Li full cell also shows excellent cycling performance. This work provides an effective strategy to modify ether-based polymer electrolytes and can boost their development in high-performance solid state lithium metal batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Nowadays, with the tremendous development of automobiles and portable electronics, solid-state lithium batteries (SSLBs) have been recognized as one of the most competitive candidates to break through the performance bottleneck of conventional rechargeable lithium batteries using flammable liquid electrolyte because of their improved safety, energy density and more stable electrochemical properties [1–3]. Solid state electrolyte is considered to be the most important part of SSLB, among which polymer electrolytes have attracted a lot of interest owing to the fascinating advantages of low cost, outstanding flexibility and easy processability [4–6].

Generally, polymer-based electrolytes can be divided into two major categories: solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) and gel polymer electrolyte (GPE). SPE is a complex of polymer matrix and Li salts, where the ion transport depends heavily on local segmental relaxation of polymer chains which mainly exists in small amorphous regions [7], resulting in low ionic conductivity (10−8 to 10−5 S cm−1) and this severely hinders the application prospects of SPE [8,9]. To address this issue, liquid plasticizers are applied to SPE to form so-called GPE. It is widely accepted that the absorbed plasticizers can effectively promote the dissociation of Li salts and assist in ion motion, which increase ionic conductivity exponentially (10−6 to 10−3 S cm−1) [10–13].

The detrimental interfacial side reactions and uncontrolled Li dendrite growth generated by lithium metal anode during the charge–discharge process have been puzzling researchers[14–16]. Therefore, it is particularly important to select solvents or plasticizers that possess excellent stability to lithium metal. Out of these, 1,3-dioxolane (DOL), a traditional ether solvent, shows promising potential [15], but it encounters the problem of narrow electrochemical window and can only be applied to battery systems below 3.0 V (such as lithium-sulfur batteries) [17–19]. To address this issue, the facile method of DOL polymerization is proposed. For one thing, the polymerization product, poly(1,3-dioxolane) (PDOL), not only inherits compatibility toward lithium, but also achieves intrinsically higher oxidation resistance which can operate stably at around 4.0 V [20–23]. And for another, partial polymerization of DOL scavenges most of the unstable solvent molecules and induces high salt concentration environment, which also contributes to good antioxidant stability [24]. 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME), another ether solvent, has been extensively studied as a plasticizer alone, or in combination with PDOL to alleviate partial crystallization in polyether [25–27]. However, it is reported that the introduction of DME small molecules may result in lower electrochemical stability and restricts its application in high voltage batteries [28]. To realize the balance between ion conductivity and high oxidation resistance, compositing polymer-based electrolytes with inorganic materials has been confirmed as an effective way [29–31]. Among inorganic fills, garnet type is currently the most studied one due to its desirable ionic conductivity and stability to Li anode [32,33]. For example, Li and co-workers introduced Ga-LLZO nanoparticles to GPE matrix to obtain a composite electrolyte which exhibits good cycling performances coupling with LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 in the voltage range of 2.8 to 4.2 V [34].

Conventionally, most GPEs are prepared by a solution-casting method accompanied with immersing the obtained dry membrane into liquid electrolyte [35,36]. Despite high ionic conductivity, these ex-situ GPEs may contain toxic solvent residues from fabrication process, which are not eco-friendly and lead to side reactions. In recent years, in-situ polymerization, which converts liquid precursor into solid electrolyte directly inside the cell, has emerged as an efficacious method that can bridge an intimate and adhesive connection between the electrolyte and electrode [37]. Typically, the method is prone to use polymer monomers with active functional groups such as epoxy [20,21,27], alkenyl [38,39], and amino [40], which can be cross-linked in the presence of initiators and specific external conditions. This technique can not only avoid pollution caused by the utilization of toxic solvents, but also optimize interface contact between electrolyte and electrodes due to the excellent fluidity and wettability of precursor solution.

The LL-GCE was fabricated by an in-situ polymerization method with the detailed preparation process shown in Fig. S1 . Firstly, lithium difluoro(oxalate)borate (LiDFOB, Aladdin) was dissolved in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL, Macklin) to form a 1 M LiDFOB/DOL solution, and poly(1,3-dioxolane) (PDOL) was obtained by heating the solution at 60 ℃ for 15 min since LiDFOB would act as an initiator to trigger the ring-opening reaction of DOL. Then poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA, Mn = 400, Aladdin) and LiDFOB (1 M) were dissolved in 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME, Macklin) and further mixed with LLZTO particles with average size of 500 nm ( Fig. S2 ). The mixture showed delamination and precipitation due to the higher density of LLZTO. The inhomogeneous solution was blended with PDOL in a certain proportion and magnetically stirred for several hours to produce a white and homogeneous solution with LLZTO nanoparticles evenly distributed thanks to the viscosity of PDOL segments. Next, a certain amount of 2,2′-Azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN, Aladdin) was added to the above solution as thermal initiator for PEGDA to form precursor solution. The precursor solution contained 5 wt% LLZTO particles and the mass ratio of DOL/DME (1: 1.5 by volume) and PEGDA was 8: 1. Finally, the well-mixed liquid precursor (30 µL) was dripped on cellulose membranes (d = 19 mm) for assembling CR2025-type cells. The cells were then heated at 70 ℃ for 1 h and the LL-GCE electrolyte was obtained via the in-situ polymerization. The electrolyte prepared by the same method but without addition of LLZTO nanoparticles was simply denoted as GPE.

Firstly, active materials LFP/LCO, Super P conductor, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder were mixed and ground evenly at a weight ratio of 8: 1: 1. Then N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, Aladdin) reagent was added to the mixture and stirred for 6 h to form a homogeneous slurry, which would be cast on Al foil and dried for 12 h in a vacuum oven at 80 ℃. The LFP and LCO cathodes were tailored with a diameter of 15 mm and a mass loading of about 2.27 and 2.60 mg cm−2, respectively. The high mass loading LFP (12.5 mg cm−2) and NCM811 (10.8 mg cm−2) cathode were purchased from Canrd Co. Ltd. After that, the precursor solution of LL-GCE was dripped on the cellulose membrane which laid on the cathode in a CR2025 coin-type cell, following by placing a piece of Li metal (300 μm) as anode. The cell was then heated at 70 ℃ for 1 h to ensure the polymerization of liquid precursor. The full cells with GPE was assembled by the same process. To be more specific, all types of cells could be fabricated via the similar method of in-situ polymerization with different electrodes.

Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20) was conducted to analyze the organic functional groups in prepared electrolytes and other samples. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Cu Kα) in the range of 10° to 80° to explore the phase composition of samples. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS GeminiSEM 300) with X-ray energy spectrometer was used to illustrate the microstructures and morphologies of electrolytes and electrodes. The Raman spectra of different samples were collected with a Thermo Scientific DXR Raman spectrometer at a Raman laser wavelength of 532 nm. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR, Bruker Avance NEO 600) was employed to estimate the polymerization degree of PDOL. To examine the thermal stability of electrolytes, thermogravimetry (TG, Netzsch STA2500) was performed under N2 atmosphere from 30 ℃ to 800 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃ min−1. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC, Netzsch DSC 200 F3) was tested from − 80 ℃ to room temperature at a heating rate of 5 ℃ min−1 to determine the glass transition temperature (T g) of electrolytes. The spectra of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source, which contained information about the components and contents of electrode surface. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100F) was used to detect the microstructure evolution of the LCO cathode surface before and after cycling.

LL-GCE or GPE electrolytes were sandwiched between a pair of stainless steel (SS, d = 15 mm) electrodes to assemble SS||SS cells, which would then be used to measure ionic conductivities of LL-GCE and GPE at various temperatures by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at frequencies ranging from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz and a potential amplitude of 10 mV on a Princeton PARSTAT MC 1000 electrochemical workstation. The ionic conductivity (σ) can be calculated using the following equation:
(1)

where L, R and S represent thickness of electrolyte, bulk resistance and area of SS electrode, respectively. The activation energy (E a) of the polymer electrolyte was calculated by Arrhenius relationship:

The Li+ transference number (t Li +) of electrolytes were evaluated by combination of EIS and direct current (DC) potentiostatic polarization method using Li|electrolyte|Li cells on the same electrochemical workstation. where I 0 and I s stand for the initial and steady current, R 0 and R s refer to the interface resistance before and after polarization, respectively, and the applied polarization potential ΔV is 10 mV. Furthermore, the electrochemical stability of electrolytes was determined by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) using SS||Li cells on a CHI660E electrochemical workstation, and the test was performed at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV/s from open-circuit voltage to 5.5 V.

The symmetrical Li||Li cells cycled at room temperature and 0 ℃ (produced by a XNIAK freezer) with different current densities to examine the chemical stability of prepared electrolytes against Li anode. Besides, the LFP||Li and LCO||Li full cells were tested at room temperature to evaluate the long-term cycling ability and rate performance of cells. All the long-term galvanostatic charge–discharge behavior and rate performance of cells were recorded on LAND CT3001A system.

DFT calculations were performed in Gaussian (G09) suite of program with Becke’s three-parameter hybrid method using Lee-Yang-Parr correlation functional (B3LYP). All the geometrical structures were optimized at 6-31G (d, p) level and then calculated at 6–311++G (d, p) level. And the solvent effects were treated by using Solvation Model Based on Density (SMD) model with solvent selected as DME (ε = 7.2).

Fig. 1
a presents the preparation schematic of LL-GCE. The designed electrolyte has a dual polymer network structure composed of PDOL and PEGDA with DME as a plasticizer and LLZTO particles as inorganic fillers. The process of cation-induced ring-opening of DOL monomers by LiDFOB is demonstrated in Fig. S3 . It is reported that LiDFOB tends to break easily to produce BF3, which can be protonized by the trace water in the solvent, and the resultant strong Lewis acid species are inclined to attack the oxygen atoms of DOL to initiate the continuous ring-opening polymerization [41,42].

FTIR, NMR and XRD tests were conducted to clarify the physicochemical properties of electrolytes. In FTIR spectra (Fig. 1 b), the intensity of peak at 921 cm−1 attributing to cyclic ether in DOL attenuates while the characteristic peak at 847cm−1 of long-chain ether vibration in PDOL emerges after polymerization [43]. Besides, the C=C stretching vibration peak at 1635 cm−1 assigned to PEGDA oligomers almost disappears after thermal cured (see molecular structure of PEGDA in Fig. S4 ) [38]. All of these structural transformations confirm the complete polymerization of PEGDA and the partial polymerization of DOL monomers. The polymerization degree of PDOL can be estimated by NMR test (see more details in SI). From 1H NMR spectra in Fig. S5 , the calculated polymerization degree of PDOL generated by 1 M LiDFOB/DOL was 96 %, and the value fell to 78 % after mixing with DME plasticizer which may be imputed to the dilution of DME solvents [28]. With addition of LLZTO particles, the polymerization degree still retained 76 %, indicating the negligible effect of the ceramics on polymerization degree. As shown in Fig. 1 c, the XRD patterns of both LL-GCE and GPE electrolytes have a broad diffraction peak ranging from 10° to 50°, suggesting that the gel polymers are almost amorphous with very low crystallinity which is favorable for Li+ conduction. In addition, the LLZTO nanoparticles exhibits an unchanged crystalline structure of typical cubic phase of LLZO with high conductivity before and after mixing and polymerization process [44], demonstrating the successful integration of ceramics into polymer matrix without conspicuous structural changes.

SEM characterization was used to illustrate the overall structures of prepared electrolytes more clearly. The cellulose membrane served as a separator between cathode and anode to prevent short circuit before in-situ polymerization and its photograph and morphology are shown in Fig. S6 . Obviously, it possesses good flexibility and a porous network structure formed by interwoven fibers, providing excellent affinity for liquid precursor solution. From the cross-sectional SEM images of LL-GCE (Fig. 1 d) and GPE ( Fig. S7 a), it is found that the liquid precursor could pass through the cellulose membrane and be well absorbed, thus evenly covering on both sides of the cellulose membrane after polymerization to form a composite membrane with a thickness of about 30 μm. Fig. 1 e and Fig. S7 b present the surface morphologies of synthesized LL-GCE and GPE respectively. Both membranes have a flat surface where the fibers underneath can be observed, and LLZTO particles are uniformly distributed in LL-GCE without distinct aggregations. The energy-dispersive spectral (EDS) mappings in Fig. S8 also prove the uniform dispersion of LLZTO particles, which can be attributed to the viscosity of PDOL chains, as mentioned in the preparation section. Just as the cellulose membrane does, the LL-GCE and GPE membranes with cellulose as self-supporting skeletons also demonstrate superior flexibility, which can be bent and folded without damage (Fig. 1 f and Fig. S7 c).

Raman spectroscopy was performed to experimentally elucidate the coordination environment of both electrolytes with results recorded in Fig. 2
a and Fig. 2 b. The cation–anion clusters can be divided into free anion (FA), loose ion pair (LIP), and intimate ion pair (IIP) according to the Li+-DFOB− distance [45], which will be embodied in the location of ring breathing peak of DFOB− [46]. In the traditional diluted ether solution (1 M LiDFOB/DME), the Li+-DFOB− ion pairs are completely separated by the solvent molecules, leading to high proportion of FAs (79.6 %) with fewer LIPs (20.4 %). When the LiDFOB concentration increases to 2 M, a small amount of IIPs appears, and the peak of C-O asymmetrical stretching from solvated DME (Li+-DME) at 872 cm−1 [47] shows a significant increase due to more DME molecules interacting with Li+, but the overall solvation configuration is still alike to that in 1 M LiDFOB/DME ( Fig. S9 ).

Afterward, GPE is obtained by blending the diluted ether solution with polymer. Considering the possible dipole–dipole interaction between solvent molecules and polymer, there is a certain increase in both LIPs (35 %) and IIPs (18.2 %). The peak of C-O symmetrical stretching from free DME at 820 cm−1 [48] remains almost unchanged along with appearance of undissociated LiDFOB. The result suggests the solubility difference of LiDFOB in regions of the GPE system, in other words, some LiDFOB stay undissociated in polymer matrix while others are dissociated by relatively excessive DME molecules. Interestingly, with ceramic fillers dispersed in GPE to form LL-GCE, IIPs become the dominant configurations (91 %), meaning more anions in Li+ solvation shell. The red-shift of Li+-DME peak also proves the weakened Li+-DME interaction. More importantly, the signal of undissociated LiDFOB is absent, representing the sufficient utilization of lithium salts, thus reducing free DME. It can be observed from Fig. S10 that the residual DOL molecules of both GPE and LL-GCE systems exist in coordinated states. [49].

We proposed a hypothesis that the Lewis acid-base interactions between introduced LLZTO and polymers could promote the dissociation of lithium salts, thus regulating the solvation structure, and FTIR was performed to assist in verifying this conjecture. As shown in Fig. 2 c, two vibrational peaks at 688 cm−1 and 562 cm−1 corresponding to La-O and Zr-O stretching mode of LLZTO respectively [50] keep in the original positions along with the addition of DME, suggesting negligible association behavior between LLZTO and DME. After blending with PEGDA, however, the La-O absorption peak shifts to lower wavenumbers which indicates the increasing of bond length caused by complexing with other functional groups. Meanwhile, the characteristic peak of C=O stretching mode at 1726 cm−1 that belongs to PEGDA moves towards low wavenumbers when mixed with LLZTO (Fig. 2 d). These analyses may imply electrostatic interactions between PEGDA and LLZTO, and the possible reaction mechanism is clarified with reference to previous works [51]. The C atom in the C=O group of PEGDA is in an electron-deficient state as it bonds with two O atoms, which will attract the nonbonding electrons of La atoms in LLZTO. As a result, C=O groups show an increased electron density and act as Lewis bases, which may facilitate dissociation of lithium salts and Li+ migration [51,52]. And the alkaline-like environment was further proved by measurement of pH value ( Fig. S11 ).

According to above research results, a simple schematic of Li+ solvation mode and conduction is presented in Fig. 2 e. The GPE system has solvent-dominated solvation structures and mainly relies on solvent molecules to transport Li+, while the polymers may block the migration of Li+ due to weak solubility to LiDFOB and inferior transfer kinetic compared with liquid phase. As for the LL-GCE system, anion-rich solvation configurations account for the majority, and a synergistic ion conduction with both polymer chains and solvent molecules involved is achieved.

The ionic conductivity, Li+ transfer number (t Li +) and electrochemical window are crucial factors influencing battery performance and the practical applications of electrolytes. From the EIS profiles in Fig. 3
a, the ionic conductivity of GPE and LL-GCE at room temperature can be calculated as 3.3 × 10−4 S cm−1 and 7.9 × 10−4 S cm−1, respectively. Fig. S12 provides a summary of ionic conductivities of GPE and LL-GCE at different temperatures along with fitting Arrhenius plots illustrating the activation energy (E a) of ion transference shown in Fig. 3 b. It is obvious that the E a of LL-GCE (0.221 eV) is significantly lower than that of GPE (0.698 eV), indicating a reduced migration barrier in LL-GCE. After incorporated with LLZTO particles, the improved conductivity and lower E a value of LL-GCE can be attributed to following two factors: on the one hand, the high proportion of dissociated lithium salts increases the concentration of Li+ as charge carriers; on the other hand, the introduced ceramics can improve the ionic conductivity by breaking the regularity of polymer chains. To further prove the point proposed, the glass transition temperature (T g) of as-prepared electrolytes were evaluated by DSC tests (Fig. 3 c). The T g of LL-GCE is evidently lower than that of GPE, illustrating that LL-GCE possesses a larger amorphous area and higher segmental movement ability that is beneficial for Li+ motion.

For such a dual-ion electrolyte system, t Li + is defined as the ratio of Li+ to all mobile ions, representing the effective transport of Li+ in the electrolyte. In liquid electrolytes, t Li + is usually less than 0.5 due to the presence of a large number of free anions. The value of t Li + in the GPE electrolyte can be calculated as 0.41 as displayed in Fig. S13 , which is very close to that of liquid electrolyte. This reveals the fact that the Li+ coordination environment and related solvation structure of GPE are very similar to liquid electrolyte, that is, part of LiDFOB is almost completely dissociated by DME which increases the ratio of FAs and LIPs, resulting in a low t Li +. While for the LL-GCE electrolyte, the existence of LLZTO particles constructs special anion-rich solvation structures, reducing the number of free anions and effectively raising t Li + to 0.83 (Fig. 3 d).

To compare the electrochemical stability of the two electrolytes, Li||SS cells were assembled for LSV tests. The electrochemical window of PDOL can surpass 5 V, corroborating intrinsically high oxidation resistance of PDOL reconstructed by DOL molecules (Fig. 3 e). To make it suitable for diverse commercial cathode materials, the electrolyte is supposed to have a wide electrochemical window. The electrochemical window of LL-GCE and GPE reach 4.78 V and 4.57 V respectively. The enhanced electrochemical stability of LL-GCE is not only related to the high oxidative stability of LLZTO itself, but also to the elimination of free ether molecules which are well recognized to be decomposed under high voltage.

In order to explore the differences on thermal stability between the two electrolytes, TG was carried out. According to the TG curves in Fig. 3 f, there are two main stages of weight loss. The first stage below 150 ℃ corresponds to the rapid evaporation and decomposition of organic solvents, and it is clearly showed in the magnified inset, where the weight loss of LL-GCE is smaller than that of GPE at the same temperature, indicating the better thermal stability of LL-GCE. Apart from the encapsulation of organic solvents in polymer framework, fewer free solvents also slow the evaporation loss of LL-GCE. The second stage corresponds to the curves after 150 ℃, where other components begin to decompose. More specifically, the decomposition of cellulose membrane and LiDFOB starts at about 300 ℃, as proved by their TG curves in Fig. S14 . Therefore, a significant mass loss is observed at around 300 ℃ in Fig. 3 f.

To examine the chemical stability of the electrolytes against Li anode, the galvanostatic Li plating/stripping behaviors were evaluated. The area capacity of charge and discharge for all tests was fixed at 0.1 mAh cm−2. The long-term cycling performance of Li||Li cells at 0.1 mA cm−2 is shown in Fig. 4
a. As for the symmetrical cell with GPE electrolyte, the initial overpotential is about 50 mV and increases visibly with cycling. Finally, a sudden voltage drop occurs at about 870 h implying a short circuit imputed to the uncontrollable Li dendrites growth. However, the Li||Li cell with LL-GCE presents a low initial overpotential of 30 mV and the polarization only slightly increases to 55 mV after cycling for more than 2000 h without short circuit. When the current density changes to 0.2 mA cm−2, the result is similar ( Fig. S15 ). The symmetrical Li||Li cell with LL-GCE can still cycle stably for over 300 h while the cell with GPE fails at only 70 h. Fig. 4 b displays the rate performance of Li||Li cells from 0.1 mA cm−2 to 1 mA cm−2. Obviously, the Li||Li cell with LL-GCE exhibits smaller overpotential than that with GPE at each current density and no short circuit appears even during cycling at 1mA cm−2 which is unbearable for the symmetrical cell with GPE. Furthermore, the Li||Li cell with LL-GCE demonstrates superior reversibility when the current density returns to 0.1 mA cm−2.

Based on the above discussion we can draw the conclusion that the LL-GCE enables more stable Li deposition/dissolution process and more effective suppression of Li dendrites. Actually, in electrolytes with mobile anions, Li ions and free anions move simultaneously but towards opposite electrodes under an applied electric field. Li ions can be consumed by depositing while anions accumulate at the electrolyte/electrode interface, forming a large concentration gradient which hinders Li+ migration. As mentioned before, LL-GCE has higher Li+ conductivity and notably elevated t Li +, which means that most anions inside are immobile, thus establishing a more harmonious environment for homogeneous and dendrite-free Li deposition.

The positive influence of the introduced LLZTO particles on Li deposition was further proved by EIS spectra of symmetrical Li||Li cells and surface images of Li anodes. Fig. 4 c presents the Nyquist plots of Li||Li cells with LL-GCE and GPE after 100 cycles, which can be divided into the Ohmic resistance (R b), the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) resistance (R S) and the charge transfer resistance (R ct). Clearly, the R S and R ct values of GPE (30.7 and 222.8 Ω) are significantly higher than those of LL-GCE (15.2 and 155.8 Ω), implying the hindered ion transport and slow reaction kinetics at the interface of GPE and Li anode. The morphologies of uncycled Li anode are provided in Fig. S16 with wrinkles on its surface caused by rolling preparation. It is worth mentioning that after cycling in LL-GCE, the Li anode can get rid of the original wrinkles and reconstruct a more reliable interface during the repeated stripping/plating process as displayed in Fig. 4 d-e, thereby inducing subsequent uniform deposition of lithium. On the contrary, a rough topography with protrusions and cracks is formed on the surface of Li anode cycling in GPE (Fig. 4 f-g), revealing severe interface issues that may lead to rapid cell failure, which echoes the EIS and galvanostatic cycling results.

XPS was employed to understand the difference of Li deposition behaviors between both electrolytes from the perspective of SEI. Fig. 4 h-i present the XPS spectra of Li anodes disassembled from Li||Li cells after 100 cycles at 0.2 mA cm−2. In C 1s spectra, the peaks at 284.8 eV and 286.3 eV can be assigned to C-C/C-H and C-O bond respectively [53]. The Li anode cycling in LL-GCE has stronger signal intensity of C-O bond originating from segments of PDOL and weaker signal intensity of C-C bond related to unwanted organic species. Additionally, F 1s spectra show that the SEI formed in LL-GCE contains abundant LiF, which is conducive to preventing the SEI layer from breaking and inhibiting Li dendrite growth due to its robust physical properties [54,55]. The designed LL-GCE electrolyte raises the content of inorganic fluorides while reducing the ratio of organic components ( Fig. S17 ), hence demonstrating superior stability against Li anode, which allows the symmetrical cell to cycle for 90 h even at a low temperature of 0 ℃ just as shown in Fig. S18 .

Given the outstanding ability to facilitate uniform Li stripping/plating, the LFP||Li full cells were tested to further evaluate the electrochemical performance of electrolytes. Fig. 5
a provides the long-term cycling performance of the LFP||Li cells at 1C (1C = 170 mA g−1) in 2.5 − 4.0 V. As expected, the cell with LL-GCE delivers a capacity of 135.4mAh/g with an ultrahigh capacity retention of 99.3 % and coulombic efficiency above 99.8 % after 250 cycles, revealing a remarkable cycling stability. Conversely, the capacity of LFP||Li with GPE decays rapidly to only 93.7 mAh/g with a much lower capacity retention of 74.6 %. Besides, smaller and stable polarization are observed in LFP||Li cell with LL-GCE compared with that with GPE according to the corresponding charge and discharge curves shown in Fig. 5 b-c. Cycling at 0.5C, the LFP||Li cell with LL-GCE still conveys a higher initial capacity of 146.6 mAh/g and capacity retention of 86.2 % than that with GPE even after 400 cycles as displayed in Fig. S19 . Although assembled with a high mass loading LFP cathode and a thin Li anode, the full cell using LL-GCE still works normally ( Fig. S20 a).

The rate performance of both electrolytes, a vital characteristic for fast-charging lithium ion battery, was also assessed and presented in Fig. 5 d. Apparently, the LFP||Li cell with LL-GCE exhibits better rate capability than that with GPE. For the LFP||Li cell with LL-GCE, remarkably high retained discharge capacities of 155.8, 152.5, 146.9, 139.5 and 127.3 mAh/g are obtained at the rate of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2C, respectively. However, despite having similar discharge capacity at 0.1C, the LFP||Li with GPE undergoes a rapid capacity decline with cycling especially at high current density. More importantly, when the current density returns to 0.1C, the discharge capacity of LFP||Li with LL-GCE can recover to 153.8 mAh/g, which is close to its initial capacity, reflecting superior reversibility. These results indicate that the composite ether-based electrolytes via in-situ polymerization are well compatible with electrodes, and the introduced LLZTO particles have a favorable effect on electrochemical performance due to enhancement on Li+ migration and redox reaction kinetics.

To evaluate the stability of both electrolytes functioning with high-voltage cathode, the LCO||Li full cells were fabricated and performed. Evidently, LL-GCE is more applicable for LCO cathode. As presented in Fig. 5 e, under the cutoff voltage of 4.3 V, the cycling performance of LCO||Li cell with GPE deteriorates severely and just delivers a reversible capacity of 61.2 mAh/g after 200 cycles at 0.5C (1C=140 mA g−1), which is less than half of its initial capacity. While for the cell with LL-GCE, it can guarantee a stable cycling without significant capacity decay and remain a capacity of 134.3 mAh/g with a much higher capacity retention of 91.6 %. With the cutoff voltage raising to 4.4 V, the corresponding charge and discharge curves of LCO||Li cells were obtained. As depicted in Fig. 5 f, the discharge capacity of GPE-derived cell degrades rapidly accompanied with a rising polarization, which might be interpreted by the severe parasitic reactions and accumulation of harmful decomposition products at the cathode-electrolyte interphase (CEI) layer. On the contrary, the LCO||Li cell with LL-GCE is able to operate normally in spite of the high voltage, confirming its strengthened oxidation resistance (Fig. 5 g). Moreover, NCM811 cathode with high mass loading is applied to further verify the excellent electrochemical stability of LL-GCE ( Fig. S20 b). As expected, the NCM811|LL-GCE|Li cell exhibits excellent electrochemical performance.

To demonstrate the practicability of LL-GCE electrolyte in SSLBs, the LCO||Li pouch cell was assembled for mechanical abuse test (Fig. 5 h). The LED can be lighted successfully whenever the pouch cell is bent, fold or cut. Furthermore, the LFP||Li pouch cell can operate stably ( Fig. S21 ), proving the great safety of the LL-GCE electrolyte and its prospect of application in flexible devices.

To further explore the antioxidation stability mechanism of prepared electrolytes, XPS depth analysis was conducted with Ar+ etching for different time periods to identify the composition and element change on the surface of cycled LCO cathodes. The F 1s, C 1s and O 1s XPS spectra are recorded in Fig. 6
a, Fig. 6 b and Fig. S22 , respectively. With respect to the CEI layer of LCO cathode cycling in LL-GCE, the LiF content synchronously increases with etching time and reaches a considerable amount when etching for 2 min ( Fig. S23 a-c), while the C-F content experiences a fast fade and eventually falls to almost zero [56]. Despite the similar variation trend, specific compositions of the CEI layer formed in GPE still differ a lot, since it has a much higher content of organic fluorides (C-F bond) at the beginning and a significantly lower content of LiF after etching for 2 min ( Fig. S23 a-c). As depicted in Fig. 6 b, GPE-derived CEI layer manifests a great intensity of C-C signal, indicating excessive decomposition of organic species, which can also be inferred from the existence of the Li2CO3 peak. Whereas, the C-O peak becomes predominant in CEI layer formed in LL-GCE, which may belong to C-O-C chains of PDOL. Besides, in O 1s spectra, the signal of lattice O of LCO cathodes cycled in GPE can be easily detected, while the signal almost disappeared in CEI layer formed in LL-GCE [57,58]. Therefore, it can be concluded that a unique organic–inorganic gradient CEI layer with organic components on the shallow surface and inorganic LiF inside the deep surface is formed on the LCO cathode cycling in LL-GCE.

Actually, a CEI layer with abundant organic substances is bonded to the cathode surface and fails to accommodate the large volume change of the cathode during lithiation/delithiation, resulting in fracture of transition metal oxide cathode and subsequent lithium consuming side reactions [54]. Whereas the inorganic-rich CEI, especially LiF-rich CEI, exhibits inherent robust properties, and suffers less strain/stress during cycling owing to its weak bonding force with cathode materials, thus maintaining structural integrity and providing protection for the cathode. In addition, benefiting from its broad electrochemical window and extremely low electronic conductivity, the LiF-rich insulating layer can effectively prevent the overactive LCO cathode from continuously reacting with electrolyte, and reduce the accumulation of organic products at the interface [59,60].

The results of SEM and TEM further prove the point proposed. Fig. 6 c presents the fresh LCO electrode and the morphology evolution of the cycled LCO cathodes in different electrolytes. Compared with LCO particles cycling in LL-GCE with a relatively smooth and intact surface, severe intraparticle crevices and discernible pulverization appear on the LCO particles after 20 cycles in GPE, which can be ascribed to the inferior structure stability of the coated organic-rich CEI layer. The TEM results reveal that a uniform and thin CEI layer derived from LL-GCE is coated on the surface of LCO electrode with a thickness of about 7 nm (Fig. 6 d), while an inhomogeneous interfacial film with a thickness of about 14 nm covers the surface of LCO electrode cycling in GPE.

From the perspective of solvation configurations, we can elucidate the reasons for the difference between CEI layers formed in the two electrolytes. In GPE, unstable uncoordinated solvents and solvent-dominated solvation structures lead to the continuous side reactions of electrolytes and an organic-rich CEI layer. In the LL-GCE electrolyte with abundant anion-rich solvation configurations, since DFOB− has a higher HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) energy than DME and DOL solvents whether it is coordinated with Li+ or not (Fig. 6 e), it can be oxidized prior to organic solvents to form a favorable LiF-rich CEI with dense, resistive and protective properties (Fig. 6 f) [24,58,61]. In addition, Li+-DFOB− exhibits lower LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) than other [Li+-solvent] complexes, inducing the preferential reduction of DFOB− on the Li anode surface, which is responsible for the high content of inorganic fluorides in SEI layer.

In summary, we prepare an ether-based gel composite electrolyte via an in-situ polymerization and highlight a collaborative approach consisting of the polymerization of DOL and the interaction between LLZTO particles and PEGDA polymer chains. The former is exploited to “concentrate” lithium salt solution, while the latter makes contributions to facilitate dissociation of lithium salts and Li+ conduction (7.9 × 10−4 S cm−1). With the cooperation of both, the Li+-DFOB− interaction is markedly reinforced to induce DFOB−-rich solvation configurations, which effectively limit the anion migration with a high t Li + of 0.83. The routine organic lithium salt, LiDFOB, besides functioning as an initiator for ring-opening polymerization of DOL, the DFOB− anions tend to be oxidized before the decomposition of other ether solvent molecules on the anode and cathode surfaces, generating SEI and CEI layers with inorganic fluorides-rich components. The LL-GCE electrolyte possesses good Li anode compatibility and enhanced oxidation resistance. The Li symmetrical cell behaves with a low polarization potential and an enlarged lifetime up to 2000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2. The electrolyte also works well matching with LFP or LCO cathodes and the full cells demonstrate superior cyclic stability. This work provides an effective approach for the rational design of ether-based polymer electrolytes to construct safe, high performance SSLBs.
